---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: PS: I apologize for miscommunication. I just realized that "Pending" comments were not visible to other users.

Let's postpone
```
instance {N : Type _} (r : ContextFreeRule T N) [BEq T] [BEq N] : DecidableRel r.RewritesTo
```
to a later PR.
游 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by ericrbg.

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6508474514/job/17677906596)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6508474514/job/17677906820)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6508474514/job/17677907377)
Looks good! I would indeed rename the file as well.
looking good generally!
lgtm!
I made a few suggestions; see inline comments. Keep in mind that I don't really do formalisation any more, so I don't really know what I'm talking about. ;)
Looks good! I would indeed rename the file as well.

lgtm, some small golfs but other than that

maintainer merge
Is there a reason you didn't make these universe polymorphic

If I change everything to `Type _` then the final definition fails:
```
invalid occurrence of universe level 'u_2' at 'IsCF', it does not occur at the declaration type, nor it is explicit universe level provided by the user, occurring at expression
  Exists.{max (u_1 + 1) (u_2 + 2)} fun g  Eq.{u_1 + 1} (CFG.language.{u_1, u_2} g) L
at declaration body
  fun {T : Type u_1} (L : Language T)  갞 (g : CFG T), CFG.language g = L
```
Probably in that definition you will have to specify the definition as there exists a CFG in the same universe as the type of the language which gives the language
this would be better in the module docstring or the inductive docstring so that it shows up in the online docs

It would be good to add some basic API about your definitions so that people can actually use them somewhat, and so that we can be sure it works as intended. Eg. in this case do we have `CFG.Derives.refl` saying that any word derives itself
Please see my new commit.
probably you should open a CFG namespace here
Do you want `open CFG` or `namespace CFG` here? I believe the former accomplishes nothing because I use the `.` notation everywhere.
It accomplishes not having to write `CFG.` everywhere, which imo helps readability
Then I have to write `namespace CFG` right? The prefix `CFG.` is written only in the declarations; calls never use it explicitly.
I don't want `IsCF` to become `CFG.IsCF` because it should be `Language.IsCF` by semantics. What should I do?

end the namespace before declaring `IsCF` (or alternatively use `_root_.Language.IsCF`
You should put the new lemmas above `IsCF` in that case, next to the defs they are lemmas about.
Is it worth opening the namespace then? Since I use the dot notation everywhere, very little will be saved by `CFG.` not being repeated.

Having `def CFG.`  as the prefix of every definition or lemma is basically working in a namespace anyway, just with more typing. With a namespace there is less chance of you or anyone later editing the file forgetting that, and its also less repeated information, which makes reading the file easier. its also easier to change the name later without changing every line.
So yes when I look at this file I immediately think "oh this should all just be in a namespace"
OK, I'll put it into a namespace then. Just tell me, should I use `g.Derives u v` or `Derives g u v` now? My switch to the former notation was motivated by not having `CFG.` prepended automatically.
I would use the first one, though I think that it would be ok either way

```suggestion
    u = w 갿갞 v : List (Symbol T g.nt), g.Transforms u v 갾 g.Derives v w  :=
```
It seems to me you made a typo. I guess what you want me to do is to remove double spaces in the whole file?

oops yes, the github suggestions box isn't monospaced. Basically we put single spaces around infix operators following https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#structuring-definitions-and-theorems (which is still a little bit lean 3ey, but that part hasn't changed as far as I know

```suggestion
lemma CFG.Derives.transforms {u v w : List (Symbol T g.nt)}
```
might enable some nice dot notation later
OK, I'll reformat the whole API like this.
In general I would say shortening derives to deri will only make people miss these lemmas when they type the name
OK.
This could be tagged `@[refl]`
OK.

```suggestion
@[trans]
lemma CFG.Derives.trans {u v w : List (Symbol T g.nt)}
```

```suggestion
```

I don't think this is needed.
why do you want to use this instead of `sum`? Just to make the purpose of both sides more obvious?
Yes.
I got several positive reactions to this design decision. For such an important data type, names are better than generic `sum`.
I think this is usually written with the syntax `{.. | ..}` instead - why are you using `setOf` directly?
I think `setOf` is less cluttered. Should I change it?

```suggestion
lemma Derives.trans {u v w : List (Symbol T g.nt)}
```

I'd stick with mathlib convention here
That would be extremely bad for readability and code intellisense because `Derives.trans` looks almost like `Derives.transforms` below.
I'm still not super certain about this but I'll defer to other peoples' thoughts about this.

Let's not discuss this lemma name in isolation. What should be the names of these three lemmas?
```
(huv : g.Derives u v) (hvw : g.Transforms v w) : g.Derives u w
(huv : g.Transforms u v) (hvw : g.Derives v w) : g.Derives u w
(huv : g.Derives u v) (hvw : g.Derives v w) : g.Derives u w
```
I strongly agree with Eric. It's transitivity, so should be called `trans`.

Please don't answer this question in isolation. I need a consistent set of names for these three lemmas:
```
(huv : g.Derives u v) (hvw : g.Transforms v w) : g.Derives u w
(huv : g.Transforms u v) (hvw : g.Derives v w) : g.Derives u w
(huv : g.Derives u v) (hvw : g.Derives v w) : g.Derives u w
```
Stop telling me that the last lemma should be called `Grammar.Derives.trans` without providing names for the other two lemmas.

going with how stuff like `trans_lt` and stuff works I'd expect `trans_transforms` and `trans_derives`, although I'm not super sure that `trans_transforms` is mega necessary (compared to say `.trans x.single`). I can see why you wouldn't be a fan of `trans_transforms`, though.

I am convinced that all three lemmas are useful. This is my usage count from my project on grammars:
(context-free version)
CF_deri_of_deri_deri
4
CF_deri_of_deri_tran
13
CF_deri_of_tran_deri
6
(general version)
grammar_deri_of_deri_deri
29
grammar_deri_of_deri_tran
22
grammar_deri_of_tran_deri
10

What about the the following naming?
```
CFG.Derives.trans
CFG.derives_of_head
CFG.derives_of_tail
```
Should this be `NT`? Not sure what mathlib naming convention says about type-valued fields.
`NT` or `Nt`?
Based on [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/wiki/Porting-wiki#naming-convention), `NT` because it's an acronym? But ask Mario if you want to be sure.
You'll probably need a predicate "derives in `k` steps" at some point. Might want to define `Derives` in terms of that.

I never needed step counting in grammars throughout all 15k lines of code I wrote. Only now when I have moved to semi-Thue systems, I defined `Derives` with step counting:
https://github.com/madvorak/thue/blob/72f7f5398b345a4ab0a398f9f496ee369f1baa7f/Thue/Definition.lean#L35

Here, I believe, it would be just another quantification that would artificially complicate the code.
Okay. If the need arises later, it'll be easy enough to prove that `Derives` is equivalent to `\ex k, DerivesIn k`.

I'm generally skeptical of using `def`s for anything that'll appear in type signatures, because computation is unreliable (depends on transparency settings and on tactics implementing it correctly). I would therefore prefer if all or most of these `Prop`s were inductives.
I never heard about this recommendation. Can I get another person's opinion, please?

To elaborate (copying from our private conversation), the tradeoff is essentially:

- `def` is more convenient when it works, but it might break mysteriously because someone forgot to check for defeq in a tactic, or because instance search works up to reducible transparency, etc.
- `inductive`/`structure` is more cumbersome (you have to fold/unfold explicitly) but more reliable.
`IsContextFree` for clarity? (If this is the accepted spelling in mathlib, please ignore).
We are the first who add context-free stuff to mathlib, so we can choose. Do others prefer `IsContextFree`?
I prefer it also, mathlib doesn't use too many acronyms to be honest
I saw a lot of acronyms in `Computability` but I don't mind changing it to the longer name.

Might be worth introducing a type `Rule T NT`, if only for nicer notation below (`r.lhs` instead of `r.fst`). I would also consider introducing types for sentence forms (is that the correct English word? I mean `List (Symbol ...)`) and words (`List T`).
I'd like to get a third opinion on this issue, please.
Type for rules done. Type for sentence forms not.

Mario suggested an alternative definition of this predicate after your talk. I'm also skeptical of the definition given here because existentials are bad for automation. But I guess a lot of your development depends on this definition, so probably not worth changing it.
Mario's suggestion was for general grammars. And the subject of debate was not existential quantification.
Okay. I don't immediately see a definition that would be clearly better, so let's leave it as it is.
I didn't see the talk I'm afraid; does the suggestion that Martin now pushed look similar to what you remember?
This is a completely different topic.

shorter as:
```suggestion
  갞 r 갣 g.rules,
```
Can you put a docstring on each constructor?
Will do!

```suggestion
/-- One step of context-free transformation: `g.Produces w w` means that a single rewrite turns `w` into `w`. -/
```

This subexpression feels suboptimal to me; it seems annoying both to prove and to use. Some things you might want to consider:
* extracting this to its own `abbrev RewritesTo (rule : NT 칑 List (Symbol T NT)) (w w : List (Symbol T g.NT))`, so that you have a namespace to add API to
* defining a custom `inductive` relation
* using a natural number index

I think these last two have the property that they should be straightforward to write a `DecidableRel` instance for, which will mean that you give the `dec_trivial` tactic a major power up for context-free grammars.

Here's what the inductive type would look like:
```lean
abbrev Rule (T N) := N 칑 List (Symbol T N)

inductive Rule.RewritesTo {T NT : Type*} (rule : Rule T NT) :
    List (Symbol T NT) -> List (Symbol T NT)  -> Prop
  /-- The replacement is at the start of the remaining string. -/
  | head (xs : List (Symbol T NT)) : rule.RewritesTo (.nonterminal rule.1 :: xs) (rule.2 ++ xs)
  /-- There is a replacement later in the string. -/
  | cons (x : Symbol T NT) {xs xs : List (Symbol T NT)} (h : rule.RewritesTo xs xs) : rule.RewritesTo (x :: xs) (x :: xs)
```
I don't understand your first suggestion. What should it do?

Does it mean that a sequence of rewriting could be evaluated by Lean, as if a deterministic function on the strings?
(always the first ocurence of rewrite-able nonterminal would be rewritten?)

The first suggestion is to simply pull out a definition
```lean4
abbrev Rule (T N) := N 칑 List (Symbol T N)

abbrev RewritesTo (rule : Rule T NT) (w w : List (Symbol T g.NT)) : Prop :=
  갞 u v : List (Symbol T g.NT),
      w = u ++ [Symbol.nonterminal r.fst] ++ v 갾 w = u ++ r.snd ++ v
```
then
```suggestion
    r.RewritesTo w w
```
My second question was about the `dec_trivial` thing, i.e., the motivation for the change.
The dec_trivial thing would mean that for any concrete language, `dec_trivial` can automatically prove whether there is a *single* rewrite between two strings.
But the other motivation is that I think it will be a lot easier to prove things using the inductive definition.
I think I get it now. Thanks!
Is there a reason you've gone for `BEq` and not `DecidableEq`?
I'll change it. Thanks!

```suggestion
inductive Symbol (T : Type*) (N : Type*)
```
and throughout

This is a lemma, so `snake_case`:
```suggestion
lemma ContextFreeRule.RewritesTo.exists_parts {N : Type _} {r : ContextFreeRule T N}
```
Nice!

I think you should drop `Generates` and keep only `language`; there's no benefit to having two definitions for the same thing here.

You should add a lemma that says `w \mem language \iff g.Derives [Symbol.nonterminal g.initial] (List.map Symbol.terminal w)`
Does the "You should add a lemma" apply to the current version or to the version after refactoring?
It's independent, you should have the lemma either way

```suggestion
abbrev Derives (g : ContextFreeGrammar T) : List (Symbol T g.NT)  List (Symbol T g.NT)  Prop :=
  Relation.ReflTransGen g.Produces
```
since the fact it's a closure may as well not be an implementation detail.

Can you rephrase these docstrings to include the fully-applied proposition?
```suggestion
/-- `g.Produces u v` means that one step of context-free transformation sends `u` to `v`. -/
```
(and throughout)

Is this referring to an operation in a subsequent PR? If so, can you move this to a `TODO` section of the docstring?

If not, can you make sure "derivation" is included in the docstring of the thing you're referring to below?
This shouldn't be in the global namespace, as other languages use `Symbol` in different ways; can you put it (and maybe all the new types) inside the `ContextFreeGrammar` namespace?

```suggestion
    rcases ih with 具빯', q', rfl, rfl具뼆r
```

춾\\\_()_/춾

```suggestion
  具빥un t  t.exists_parts, by rintro 具빯, q, rfl, rfl具; apply rewritesTo_of_exists_parts具뼆r
```
this name isn't great but I can't think of a better one so; it'd be nice if you could have something like `r.Rewrites p to q` but alas
I renamed `RewritesTo` to `Rewrites` to make it less ugly.
PS: Thank god for the gray background behind code blocks on GitHub!
I think the comment is unnecessary, and maybe `deriving Fintype` would be nice too?
`Repr` would be another good one.
default handlers have not been implemented yet, class: 'Fintype' types: [Symbol]
I think you're probably just missing an import
I pushed the fix

```suggestion
lemma ContextFreeRule.RewritesTo.exists_parts {N : Type*} {r : ContextFreeRule T N}
```
and throughout

application type mismatch
  RewritesTo ?m.1518 ?m.1539 v
argument
  v
has type
  List (Symbol T N) : Type (max u_2 u_1)
but is expected to have type
  List (Symbol ?m.1486 ?m.1487) : Type u_2
These are the universe issues that Eric was referring to
I wasn't able to reproduce this
I'm pretty sure this is not what `refl` is for.
Why did you resolve this?

Oh, I'm sorry. I overlooked what you were referring to. I thought it was 
```
@[refl]
lemma Derives.refl
```
which I removed. Sorry for the mistake.

Either
```suggestion
```
or
```suggestion
@[simp]
```
which would make this work with `dsimp`
Just to be clear, `Derives.refl` is fine to tag with `@[refl]`, so you should add that attribute back there.
Thank you!

```suggestion
lemma mem_language_iff (g : ContextFreeGrammar T) (w : List T) :
```
and probably `@[simp]`
Please write this style of docstring for `Derives` and `RewritesTo` as well.
Will do!

```suggestion
lemma Derives.refl (w : List (Symbol T g.NT)) : g.Derives w w :=
```

Note there is a subtlety here about universes. It might be clearest to write
```suggestion
structure ContextFreeGrammar.{uNT uT} (T : Type uT) where
  /-- Type of nonterminals -/
  NT : Type uNT
```
which means almost exactly the same thing, but then "the type of CFGs with non-terminal symbols in universe `w`" is spelt `ContextFreeGrammar.{w} T` instead of `ContextFreeGrammar.{_ w} T`
I don't want this.
Which bit don't you want? All my change does is remove the need for the underscore
I don't want to clutter my code so much. My suggestion is to revert everything in this file to `Type`. Nobody wants to work with grammars over higher universes anyways.

Your code has always supported grammars over higher universes: the comparison is:

* `Type _` let lean choose the universes for you by magic (this often makes things messy)
* `Type*` let lean choose the universe *names* for you by enumeration (`u_1, u_2`, ...)
* `Type uNT`: name them yourself

Any time you put a type within a structure (which is a reasonable choice here), you have more universe variable issues to worry about than usual.
Note that this clutter can be reduced by removing the `{}` and putting it on a `universes` line.
I pushed the change I was suggesting; it also makes the goal states easier to read since now you see `T : Type uT` instead of `T : Type u_1`.

Thanks for the commit! I am happy that it now works.

Nevertheless, I'd prefer the old version that allowed `Type` only. The code is significantly more cluttered now.
What's the advantage of moving `N` into the declaration here? You have four delcarations in a row that use it, so it's a bit easier to read on the `variable` line
The advantage is that now `N` is no longer in the context in the whole rest of the file when `N` must not be used anymore (because `g.NT` dictates the nonterminal type).
I think a `section` around the `ContextFreeRule` lemmas would probably be a good solution too
OK, I'll make a section.

I think generally we prefer not to indent docstrings
```suggestion
/-- Given a context-free grammar `g` and strings `u` and `v`
`g.Derives u v` means that `g` can transform `u` to `v` in some number of rewriting steps. -/
```
(this applies throughout)
Can you briefly mention `ContextFreeGrammar.language`, which looks to be the main definition in this file?
@kmill: should the derive handled automatically document these?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Computability/CFG): define context-free grammars

Looks good! I would indeed rename the file as well.

Let's postpone
```
instance {N : Type _} (r : ContextFreeRule T N) [BEq T] [BEq N] : DecidableRel r.RewritesTo
```
to a later PR.
